Hey all - Bloomberg is looking to run GPDB on RHEL 8.4.  As far as I can tell, we do not support RHEL 8 at this time.  Do we have plans to support GPDB 6 on RHEL 8.x?  If so, do we have a target date?

replies.text: We definitely don't support RHEL 8 yet. It's only supported for the Greenplum 6 Clients specifically.It's on the roadmap for Q4.

@Kris do we have more accurate ETA for Q4?

Not yet unfortunately. There are complications with how we support an inplace, with data, upgrade from RHEL 7 to RHEL 8. It might be that we release support for GP 6 on RHEL 8 without that inplace upgrade first. This might come slightly sooner then figuring out the inplace upgrade.
Teams are actively working on the RHEL 8 support topic, so it shouldn't be long before we have a materialized estimation.

@here question about partition maintenance. IHAC who has a table structured like this:
CREATE TABLE RP_TESTS.RP_INT_DEFAULT_LIST_SUBP
(
  RP_INT   INTEGER,
  RP_DATE DATE,
  RP_TIMESTAMP TIMESTAMP,
  RP_DIST_KEY INTEGER NOT NULL,
  RP_SUBPART CHAR(1)
)
WITH (
    APPENDONLY=TRUE
    ,COMPRESSTYPE=ZLIB
    ,COMPRESSLEVEL=9
    ,ORIENTATION=COLUMN
)
DISTRIBUTED BY (RP_DIST_KEY)
PARTITION BY RANGE(RP_INT)
    SUBPARTITION BY LIST(RP_SUBPART)
      SUBPARTITION TEMPLATE (
       SUBPARTITION A VALUES ('A'),
       SUBPARTITION B VALUES ('B'),
       SUBPARTITION C VALUES ('C')
      )
(
    START (2017) INCLUSIVE
    END (2021) EXCLUSIVE EVERY (1),
    DEFAULT PARTITION default_part
);
ie. They have a range partition on year (the 2017 - 2021 in this example) along with a default partition.  They also have list subpartitions (A,B,C in this example).  They want to add a new year partition to the table but hit the below known restrictions:gpadmin=# alter table "rp_tests"."rp_int_default_list_subp" add partition start (numeric '2021.0') INCLUSIVE end (numeric '2022.0') EXCLUSIVE;
ERROR: cannot add RANGE partition to relation "rp_int_default_list_subp" with DEFAULT partition "default_part"
HINT: need to SPLIT partition "default_part"however, when try to do split partition you get:gpadmin=# alter table "rp_tests"."rp_int_default_list_subp" split default partition start (numeric '2021.0') INCLUSIVE end (numeric '2022.0') EXCLUSIVE;
ERROR: cannot split partition with child partitions
HINT: Try splitting the child partitions.I can't figure out a good way to work around these restrictions.  Is the only way to drop the default partition, add the new partition and re-add back in the default partition?  This is the only structure I don't currently support in my partition maintenance script and of course this is the structure this customer uses the most

I have a client need to run a large number of insert and delete every week, which has heavy impact on the performance of whole GPDB clusters. It is found that only VACUUM FULL can help to improve the performance, while it's not a convenient solution as VACUUM FULL would block other tasks.

Is this GP6? is gp_workfile_compression set? @Jonathan I am working with a US customer with kind of similar scenario (large # of spill).

Also, is it possible to isolate the insert from the deletes?  VACUUM frees up the unused space in the file that was occupied by the deleted record and reorganizes the data staring from the front of the file.  So, a delete would leave a blank spot in the file that VACUUM will clean up, thus moving all operations to the end of the file which is free and ready for data.  Also, as Shailesh suggested, partitions organized around the predicates used for the deletes would allow for partition swapping which should be substantially faster.
Has anyone ever seen Ethernet over InfiniBand used as the interconnect for a Greenplum cluster?   If so, any comments good or bad?   Thanks,

I have a client who is trying to migrate data from GPDB5 to GPDB6.
They tried to load a table of 2.5 billion records from GPDB5 to GPDB6 by pgdump and pgrestore, while the process is still running over 10 days.
Is there any way to confirm the status, or any suggestion for a better solution?

replies.text:
If there is a network connection between two clusters, gpcopy will be much faster -- it is better to create schema on the target before copying data through gpcopy https://gpdb.docs.pivotal.io/data-copy/2-3/gpcopy.htmlOr gpbackup & gprestore would be another option
https://gpdb.docs.pivotal.io/backup-restore/1-13/utility_guide/admin_utilities/gpbackup.html

@Mulong Chen
Many thanks.
If use gpcopy, does the source table and target table need to be identical? Does it for creating target in GPDB6 with partition while not with source table in GPDB5?
The schema doesn't have to be identical. As long as the target table contains all the columns to be copied. Actually, you can use sql to transform the source rows.
Pgdump & pgrestore os really a bad idea for this... Just too slow and non parallel...

@Mulong Chen
Sorry for making you confused.
The table in GPDB5 which hold 2.5 billion records is defined without partition. And the customer want to load the all records to a table in GPDB6 with partition defined
So the question is how to load data from a no-partitioned table into a partitioned table.
This should just work as a normal copying. But for vice versa, you may need to set --parallelize-leaf-partitions to false

posts.text: rhetorical question: if I have 2 tables that are identical and both are DISTRIBUTED RANDOMLY, why does this SQL 'insert into tableA select * from tableB' involve a REDISTRIBUTE motion? Couldn't you just read from one and dump to the other segment by segment without involving the network? I understand that random is not truly random but since you don't care about the distribution anyway why the reshuffle? I ask because if they are distributed by the same column(s), there is not redistribute motion shown in the plan.

replies.text: For a start... DISTRIBUTED RANDOMLY is not deterministic, and distribution for a join has to be. So joining two randomly distributed tables will involve redistribution on the join key.
I don't think that the planners (either of them) recognise random distribution of output as a reason to skip the redistribution.
This is a design decision. On Teradata the behavior of Random Distribution (NOPI) is as you say due to the idea that this type of distribution would be used on ETL processes. @aashwin @raghavanve

In this case there is no join. It is simply retrieving and dumping rows from one table to another. And I bring up the question because if the two tables involved are distributed by the same key, the optimizer makes the decision to not redistribute. I know this is an edge/special case so I really asking if there would be any downside.
I think we redistribute even if the tables have a key and the key is the same, which is kind of a nonsense….
I checked the explain of an INSERT ... SELECT where the two tables are distributed on the same key. I saw no motion. I will check again and on other tables to verify.
really/ Maybe I am remembering it wrong then… I remember it taking way too much time in a simple insert-select, maybe I am confusing the reason with the lack of scalability on that operation…

We found an interesting behaviour with partitioning:

replies.text: Definitely not in partitioning, that’s expected behavior. Gpupgrade can’t handle this case. Reason being on new cluster full hierarchy is created root to child with that column not present. Which means new and old cluster are not binary compatible for this partition hierarchy. Ideally, when creating table on new cluster should be able to create hierarchy in same fashion (dropped column for root) and not present for child. Our current partition syntax had limitation and hence upgrade had to put that check in place.@kalen @shivram @dpandhi to provide more details and fyi….

Thanks Venki.
Jira created
https://jira-pivotal.atlassian.net/browse/MPP-32026

@iputyatin This check was in place by design as pointed. Original commit can be found here https://github.com/greenplum-db/gpdb/commit/17fbcf5f568687afe96ef3a9862808059ac8a40b. We'll follow up on the jira on next steps
@iputyatin we've posted the rationale behind this consistency check and also the resolution/workaround in the jira https://jira-pivotal.atlassian.net/browse/MPP-32026?focusedCommentId=457775

posts.text: Does anyone has already used this api : https://gpdb.docs.pivotal.io/6-20/ref_guide/extensions/gppc.html#topic_spi?

replies.text: its used by IRS, us gov
Questions from one of my customer

Over the years we wrote many UDFs in C using the Postgres C language API.
These functions are working well for quite some time now, and provide a great performance enhancement over corresponding UDFs we implemented in other languages.Today I encountered an article about GPPC - a Greenplum alternative to the Postgres API.The questions are:
for my understanding, GPPC is used to avoid recompiling the C code when Greenplum verstion upgrading. it is to solve the ABI change

the GPPC provide almost the same interface as postgres. client application just need to link to gppc.so which link to the real postgres libraries.
when upgrading, the API and ABI of gppc.so won't change so the client tools don't need recompiling. some BI tools (SAS, as far as I know) relies on GPPC abi to work with different Greenplum major version (edited)
so, we would suggest to use postgres API directly so long as we could recompile the code with each greenplum release.

Hey all, question around our DR solutions with Greenplum. We're currently working on a proposal for a customer who needs a Greenplum cluster in NY and a Greenplum cluster in the UK. The NY cluster is read/write (they run their ETL jobs there) and the UK cluster is read only but it does server as an edge cluster for EU users. Their SLA's for disaster recovery are 2 hours for their main services which require the bulk of Greenplum data (lets just call it 20TB for now but that will grow). I don't have any recovery time objectives or recovery point objects although I'm thinking that the 2 hours is a recovery time objective (going to follow up with the customer on clarifying this). @Kris, i saw your sharing of GP Mirrorless and Powerflex discussion with @jchiu and @dminmin, and there was this question about Compute-Storage Affinity. So i began to wonder, when we use storage that’s separated from compute, assuming the bandwidth is not a bottleneck:

replies.text: As Ivan mentioned, distribution key best practices are still important. From Greenplum's perspective, it's still MPP. Each segment only has access to a set amount of data, so it's important to minimize processing skew.While the storage system acts as one pool available across compute hosts, there are still many storage nodes that can have their own topic of skew.I believe there is still room to understand the architecture more. We haven't researched in deep depth the more complicated relationship of compute and storage node skew in a two-tier system.

posts.text: distribution keys are still important in virtual, if you join Greenplum will scan data redistribute to do a join if distribution keys are not considered
also if you dont consider distribution keys you can have skew in processing of segments

Hi, one of the server completely went down in a GPDB Cluster due to hardware failure. All the transactions were retried after the mirror switch-over except for the queries/jobs for the GPFDIST process. Customer had to manually retrigger the Jobs related GPFDIST process as they timed out and failed. We would like to know why only GPFDIST process cannot auto retry the failed process after mirror takes the role of primary after server failure. Is this a bug, what is the mitigation strategy for the same.

replies.text: Gpdb doesn’t auto retry transactions on failover to mirror. What external software is in play at customer doing it, you will have to check that piece to answer your question

I have checked and as per logs and the customer, the transaction were auto retried after switch over to mirror. The GPFDIST file loading process queries (where the external tables are used) didnt. It got timed out(which makes sense as single server went down). But as per client it was supposed retried. They use bash scripts and also throguh informatica to invoke the gpfdist process

replies.text: Our doc notes:
Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).
Found this in an old .sql someone sent me a long time a go
maybe it helps

pg_column_size() gives per column size for tuple. AO doesn't compress single column, it compresses multiple columns in a block. So, pg_column_size() is providing the uncompressed size and understand its little misleading in AO context due to compression. But there is not way to get single column compression value as we don't compress single column but bulk batch of it.We do have plan to provide compression_ratio at column level granularity instead of only table level currently.the SQL posted by Luis will help only for GPDB5 and lower. Not for GPDB6 or higher.One can look into pg_aoseg EOF values and get the result currently which is complicated SQL. Let me try to provide one.
This might give high-level idea per column on size and compression ratio for CO tables

Hey all, I'm currently working with Autozone on trying to recover their production Greenplum system. They're on GPDB 4.2 and RHEL 5.8 (I know how scary that sounds ) and since they don't have support they've hired professional services to help. They currently have 46 segments down on 3 nodes in their production system and those 46 segments have been down since October 8th 2022 (it's a miracle the system is still available and they didn't have a double fault). I've been working with them the past 2 weeks or so trying to nail down what's going on and I feel I'm pretty close but don't know what to make of it. Basically when trying to recover the segments with gprecoverseg, all of the downed segments fail to startup and when I look at the startup logs for all of those segments, they all have the same error2023-01-10 21:10:43.741047 CST,,,p601,th-630814816,,,,0,,,seg-1,,,,,"LOG","XX000","could not create IPv6 socket: Address family not supported by protocol (pqcomm.c:381)",,,,,,,,"StreamServerPort","pqcomm.c",381,
2023-01-10 21:10:43.856942 CST,,,p601,th-630814816,,,,0,,,seg-1,,,,,"LOG","00000","temporary files using default filespace",,,,,,,,"primaryMirrorPopulateFilespaceInfo","primary_mirror_mode.c",2501,
2023-01-10 21:10:43.857190 CST,,,p601,th-630814816,,,,0,,,seg-1,,,,,"LOG","00000","transaction files using default pg_system filespace",,,,,,,,"primaryMirrorPopulateFilespaceInfo","primary_mirror_mode.c",2561,Their /etc/hosts isn't referring to IPV6 addresses for anything and when I use traceroute all of the entries in the catalog resolve to ipv4 addresses. I can't find anything specifically in the GPDB settings that specifies the use of IPV4 or IPV6 and I'm a bit stuck at the moment with this. I'm able to reproduce this issue on their environment by running netcat like nc -l 40001 -6 (the -6 specifies IPV6) and I get the same error, but when I bind to a TCP socket via IPV4 with the same command it works fine. Is there something I'm missing here or maybe someone with some ancient 4.2 knowledge might know of a bug that existed?For what it's worth, I had them collect all of their change requests from the past year and send them to me and the only thing that might be related was some networking changes that happened in April of 2022, however they bounced the database every weekend and the segments have been down since October 2022 so I'd be surprised if those 2 things are related, however as we all know most issues occur when changes happen in a system (edited)

Hi All, A query regarding GP mirrorless having better performance as compared to mirrored deployment. The analogy for the same is that WAL is set to minimal in mirrorless as no data replication between primary and mirror segments.
Do we have any quantifiable/reference data to support this in terms of how much resource does mirroring replication usually consumes if WAL level is set to higher level (WAL_LEVEL =replica)?

replies.text:
Here is a benchmark done last year on data load runtimes and how WAL affects it. This was only one test so take it with a grain of salt.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1yx68JuFQPIm-JuAVkyK5VOWy5FADny7TmExnXvybx-0/edit?usp=sharing
#gp-virtual team may have more up to date information
Thank you @bdoil, really appreciate the help

High-level - appendoptimized tables data don't at all need to be WAL'd with WAL_LEVEL=replica. So, if using appendoptimized tables then the benefit is huge as disk IO and n/w bandwidth will be lower for loads and I/U/D for these tables.

Hi All, In GP or postgres : How can we ensure to not commit if the transaction fails midway ? For example: I tried placing INSERT in a BEGIN END block but behaves the same way. Also preceded the INSERT query with  “\set AUTOCOMMIT off” in SQL script but same result.

replies.text: BEGIN INSERT END is one single transaction that commits on END (END is the same thing as COMMIT).  Similarly, BEGIN INSERT INSERT DELETE UPDATE INSERT END is one single transaction.  In the second example, if any DML failed, the transaction would be aborted and none of the changes would be committed.  Is that what you’re asking about?
Thanks Jimmy for your response. In first  example (BEGIN INSERT END) - what if INSERT fails midway : none of the changes should be committed in this case too ?

If the INSERT fails, then the changes would not be committed.  The transaction would be marked as failed.  The failed data could still be there but would not be visible by users and would get cleaned up on the next VACUUM.
Thanks Jimmy, this helps. (edited)

Hi folks, I'm wondering where the right place is to ask questions regarding postgresql configuration and in particular, advice on tunables for a 64 core vm not using all the cores for postgresql in concourse.  It's mainly a postgresql configuration question, not specific to greenplum, but since you guys deal with postgresql so much, I'd thought I'd give it a try over here.  I am the Tanzu TAM for Desjardins.  Basically I am looking for any help to get some best practices with postgresql and help them utilize all their vm cores in postgresql.  I think that postgresql tunables are the first place to look, but am looking for a good guide on that. (edited)

replies.text: @jonelson In a nutshell, more cores for PostgreSQL allows for higher concurrency and parallel operations in queries. If starved for cpu time, core counts do have an impact on replication and other db tasks such as autovacuum. Rule of thumb for performance tuning are 3 non-core related things:

6.24 will have an exciting new feature
Catalog Query Bypass
This is the first feature in the category of Short Query Bypass, and will enable catalog queries to skip the concurrency constraints of the resource group that they are run within.  So for example imagine a use case where there are 50 users in a RG and they all use a GUI like DBeaver or other, and the GUI issues 10 catalog queries, that will generate 500 queries but the RG may be full with queries that are running long running queries.  Now these catalog queries will run immediately on the Master node and bypass the RG concurrency limit. (edited)

replies.text: AFAIK, digest() in pgcrypto is something similar cc @rlei https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/pgcrypto.html (edited)
This work well for hash4

CREATE FUNCTION adler32(input text)
 warehouse-# RETURNS text
 warehouse-# AS $$
 warehouse$# import zlib
 warehouse$# return zlib.adler32(input)
 warehouse$# $$ LANGUAGE plpythonu;
I need the same for returning 64 bit or for hash()
did you try import hashlib?
The equivalents for hash4() and hash8() are the Postgres internal datatype hash functions - there's a list in the StackOverflow answer at https://stackoverflow.com/a/69650940/28158
They're regarded as internal functions, so you can use safely in a query, but don't materialise the return values because they may change between versions. Unlikely, but... (edited)

replies.text: Questions on the customer’s request:
I will ask your questions to the 3rd party tool R&D.

@clintz Hi, Postgresql logical decoding can not be used in greenplum. Because Greenplum is a distributed system, and the wal log is also distributed in each segment. It is far more difficult to implement logical decoding for distributed systems. That is also what dataflow team is trying to do.
What Zhenghua asked is also what we really care about. We are also searching for customers who have the specific requirements about CDC, so that we can have some priorities about the issues that we are to deliver in the first stage of CDC.

Worked with @jiangal, we found some interesting things:
as @jiangal’s theory, because coordinator also has several segments, those segments may use 127.0.0.1 to resolve the QE's address, but if this address is dispatched to other hosts for motion communication, the destination port on those hosts actually didn't open, so  caused connection timeout. So recommend don't deploy segments on the same host with coordinator. cc @fsidi (edited)

posts.text: Hello R&D team, One Chinese bank customer recently encountered WARNING: oldest xmin is far in the past (seg189 58.60.201.18:6009 pid=76049) when vacuum any tables in their user db, we checked and confirmed that there is no long running idle or non-idle query from pg_stat_activity, no pg_prepared_xacts even when connected to seg189 via utility mode, gpstate -s implies the primary was synchronized.. while being aware of this might be resolved after restarting the db, they are still eager to know how this could happen? they are running on 6.19.3

replies.text: More information, they found this issue when they trying to vacuum a user table on 2023-06-06 when they trying to manually vacuum a user table, however, looking back into seg189, the warning started even earlier, on 2023-06-04, since they didn't issue any VACUUM at that time, could this come from autovacuum to template0? We would be really appreciated for any of your insights! (edited)

They are close to the xid wraparound age (we see evidence on hyxf_adb and gpperfmon.) Recommendation would be to take downtime and run vacuum freeze on all databases.
Found these articles:
https://community.pivotal.io/s/article/About-XIDs-and-XID-Wraparound-in-Greenplum?language=en_US
and https://community.pivotal.io/s/article/Warning-database-XXXX-must-be-vacuumed-within-YYYY-transactions?language=en_US> could this come from autovacuum to template0?
No this has nothing to do with template0 autovacuum. (edited)

sorry, my bad, I forgot to check the orphan session on seg189 and there seems to be one leftover running since 2023-05-17 only on that segment, I'll further confirm with the customer and feedback about the age things as well
the age seems to be fine, once I terminated that orphan process on seg189 this warning just gone, thank you so much for answering me!

posts.text: Is there a particular reason why we recommend updating /etc/sysctl.conf directly instead of using a file in /usr/lib/sysctl.d or /etc/sysctl.d? (edited)

replies.text: For my local GP6 and GP7 clusters, I use a file in /etc/sysctl.d/ called local.conf. I "prefer" using /etc over /usr/lib because a general recommendation seems to be that config in /etc is for the local system user while /usr locations are for packages to install. Just my .
Thanks, that's what I do as well (add a file into /etc/sysctl.d/).  Just seems like us recommending updating /etc/sysctl.conf isn't the right way to go.

posts.text: i think our recommendations pre-dated that option 10+ years ago, they are equivalent
